Chapter 5 Software Project Management 
 
Project scheduling 
Project scheduling is a process that allows you to create a schedule that you can 
use to keep track of tasks and deadlines within a project. Project scheduling is a 
mechanism to communicate what tasks need to get done and which organizational 
resources will be allocated to complete those tasks in what timeframe.  It provides 
like  start  and  end  date  of  the  project,  milestones  and  tasks  for  the project. It 
specifies  the  resources  like  people,  equipment  etc.  required  to  complete  the 
project and dependencies   of tasks of the project on each other. 
Project Scheduling Process: 
Project schedules may simply be represented in a table or spreadsheet showing 
the tasks, effort, expected duration, and task dependencies. Project scheduling is 
the process of deciding how the work in a project will be organized as separate 
tasks, and when and how these tasks will be executed. 
 
1. Identify Activities: 
Break the whole project into smaller, manageable tasks/activities. Each activity 
should  have  a  clear  start  and  end  point. Example:  In  a  software  project – 
requirements gathering, design, coding, testing, deployment. 
2. Identify Activity Dependencies: 
Determine the sequence of activities. Some activities can start only after another 
finishes (dependent tasks). 
Dependencies are usually of four types: 

Finish-to-Start (FS): Task B starts after Task A finishes. 
Start-to-Start (SS): Task B can start when Task A starts. 
Finish-to-Finish (FF): Task B can finish only when Task A finishes. 
Start-to-Finish (SF): Rare; Task B can finish only when Task A starts. 
3. Allocate Resources: 
Assign resources (equipment, software tools, budget, materials) needed for each 
activity. Ensure resources are available when required to avoid project delays. 
4. Create Project Charts: 
Use tools like: 
Gantt Chart → Shows timeline of activities, start/end dates, and progress. 
PERT/CPM Chart → Shows dependencies and critical path. 
These charts help visualize the workflow, dependencies, and time allocation. 
5. Allocate People to Activities: 
Assign the right team members based on their skills and availability. Define roles 
and responsibilities clearly. Avoid overloading one person with too many tasks 
at the same time. 
 
Work Breakdown Structure  
A Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) is a hierarchical decomposition of a project 
into smaller, more manageable parts (modules, tasks, and activities). It helps in 
planning,  scheduling,  resource  allocation,  cost  estimation,  and  tracking  the 
progress of a software project. The root of this tree (structure) is labelled by the 
Project name itself. For constructing a work breakdown structure, each node is 
recursively  decomposed  into  smaller  sub-activities,  until  at  the  leaf  level,  the 
activities become undividable and independent. It follows a Top-Down approach. 
 
 

Features of WBS 
 Breaks complex projects into manageable components. 
 Each level gives more detail (from broad project → to modules → to tasks 
→ to activities). 
 Follows a hierarchical tree structure. 
 Supports project scheduling and resource allocation. 
Levels of WBS in Software Engineering 
Level 1 – Project Goal 
The complete software system (e.g., "Library Management System"). 
Level 2 – Major Modules / Deliverables 
Requirements Analysis, System Design, Implementation, Testing, Deployment, 
Maintenance 
Level 3 – Sub-Modules / Activities 
Requirements  Analysis  →  Gather  requirements,  Document  requirements, 
Validate requirements. 
System Design → High-level design, Database design, UI design. 
Implementation → Coding, Integration. 
Testing → Unit testing, Integration testing, System testing. 
Deployment → Installation, User training. 
Maintenance → Bug fixing, Updates. 
Level 4 – Work Packages 
The smallest manageable task assigned to individuals.

Activity Network 
an activity network is a graphical representation of a project's tasks, showing their 
dependencies  and  logical  sequence. It  uses  nodes  for  activities  and  arrows  to 
illustrate  the  flow  and  relationships  between  them,  including  both  parallel  and 

sequential  tasks. This  visual  tool  helps  in  planning,  tracking,  and analysing a 
software project. 
There  are  two  ways  of  showing  activities  and  their  relationships.  Activity  on 
Nodes (AON) and Activity on Arrows (AOA). 
In AON network diagram, activities are represented by circles or ovals and the 
sequence in which the activities have to be carried out is shown by 'arrows'. 
 
The  circles  representing  the  activities  are  labeled as  A,  B,  C  and  so  on.  The 
duration of an activity is shown below the labels. The arrows show the sequence 
in which the activities need to be executed. 
The activities of the above project can also be represented by the AOA network 
diagram. 
 
 
In the AOA network diagram, activities are represented by arrows. The nodes are 
the  events  that  are  either  the  beginning  or  end  of  activities.  The  nodes  are 
numbered  serially  and  the  activities  are  identified  by  their  start  and  end  node 
numbers. 
 
 

Project Tracking 
Project  Tracking is  the  process  of monitoring,  measuring,  and  controlling  the 
progress of a software project to ensure it stays on schedule, within budget, and 
meets the planned quality standards. 
1. Timeline Chart 
A Timeline Chart is a graphical representation of the schedule of activities in a 
software project, showing when tasks start, how long they take, and when they 
end. 
It  helps  visualize  project  progress  over  time  and  is  often  used  for  planning, 
tracking, and communicating project status. The main aim of timeline chart is to 
make it easier to capture a process as a sequence of events and to understand all 
dependencies  within  a  project,  estimating  the  time  that  it  takes  every  step  or 
money that will be needed to complete it.  
 Purpose of a Timeline Chart 
 Shows the sequence and duration of project activities. 
 Helps identify overlaps and dependencies. 
 Provides a clear schedule overview for the team and stakeholders. 
 Useful for monitoring deadlines and adjusting resources. 
  Example: Timeline Chart for a Library Management System 
    Phases and Duration: 
 Requirement Analysis → 2 weeks 
 System Design → 2 weeks 
 Development → 4 weeks 
 Testing → 2 weeks 
 Deployment → 1 week

2. Earned Value Analysis (EVA)  
Earned Value Analysis (EVA) is also called "Budget cost of work performed". 
Earned  Value  Analysis  (EVA) is  a project  management  technique used  to 
measure  a  software  project’s  performance  in  terms  of cost  and  schedule. It 
integrates cost, schedule, and scope to provide a comprehensive view of project 
health.  EVA helps assess whether a project is on track, under budget, or ahead 
of schedule, enabling proactive decision-making. 
Key Concepts in EVA: 
 Planned Value (PV): 
The  budgeted cost  of  the  work  planned  to  be  completed  by  a  certain  point  in 
time. It represents the value of the work that should have been accomplished. 
 Earned Value (EV):

The budgeted cost of the work actually completed by a certain point in time. It 
represents the value of the work that has been accomplished. 
 Actual Cost (AC): 
The real cost incurred to complete the work performed by a certain point in time. 
Example in Software Engineering: 
Consider a software development project with a total budget of $100,000 and a 
planned  duration  of  10  weeks. After  5  weeks  (mid-point  of  the  project),  the 
following data is collected: 
 Planned Value (PV): At 5 weeks, 50% of the project should be completed, so 
PV = 50% of $100,000 = $50,000. 
 Earned Value (EV): The project team has completed features worth 40% of the 
total project scope. So, EV = 40% of $100,000 = $40,000. 
 Actual Cost (AC): The actual expenses incurred up to this point are $45,000. 
EVA Metrics Calculation: 
 Schedule Variance (SV): 
SV = EV - PV = $40,000 - $50,000 = -$10,000. 
A negative SV indicates the project is behind schedule. 
 Cost Variance (CV): 
CV = EV - AC = $40,000 - $45,000 = -$5,000. 
A negative CV indicates the project is over budget. 
 Schedule Performance Index (SPI): 
SPI = EV / PV = $40,000 / $50,000 = 0.8. 
An SPI less than 1 indicates the project is behind schedule.  
 Cost Performance Index (CPI): 
CPI = EV / AC = $40,000 / $45,000 = 0.89. 
A CPI less than 1 indicates the project is over budget. 
 
In this example, the negative SV and CV, along with SPI and CPI values less than 
1, indicate that the software project is both behind schedule and over budget at 
the 5-week mark. This information allows the project manager to identify issues 
early  and  take  corrective  actions,  such  as  reallocating  resources,  adjusting  the 
scope, or revising the schedule, to bring the project back on track. 
3. Gantt chart 
 Generalized Activity Normalization Time Table (GANTT) chart is type of 
chart in which series of horizontal lines are present that show the amount of work 
done  or  production  completed  in  given  period  of  time  in  relation  to  amount 

planned  for  those  projects. A  Gantt  chart  is  a  visual  tool  used  in  project 
management to illustrate a project schedule. It displays the start and end dates of 
various tasks within a project, represented as horizontal bars against a timeline. 
It is similar to bar chart. It visualizes a project schedule from start to finish. It is 
simply  used  for  graphical  representation  of  schedule  that  helps  to  plan  in  an 
efficient   way,   coordinate,   and   track   some   particular   tasks   in   project.  
 
The purpose of Gantt chart is to emphasize scope of individual tasks. Hence set 
of  tasks is given  as input  to  Gantt  chart.  Gantt  chart is  also  known  as timeline 
chart. It can be developed for entire project or it can be developed for individual 
functions. In most of projects, after generation of timeline chart, project tables are 
prepared. In project tables, all tasks are listed in proper manner along with start 
date and end date and information related to it.  
 
Project Scheduling Techniques 
Critical Path Method 
In project management, the critical path is the longest sequence of tasks that must 
be completed to execute a project. The tasks on the critical path are called critical 
activities  because  if  they’re  delayed,  the whole  project  completion  will  be 
delayed. To find the critical path, project managers use the critical path method 
(CPM). 

What Is the Critical Path Method (CPM)? 
The critical path method (CPM) is a project management technique that’s used 
by  project  managers  to  create  an  accurate project  schedule. The  CPM  method, 
also known as critical path analysis (CPA), consists in using the CPM formula 
and a network diagram to visually represent the task sequences of a project. Once 
these task sequences or paths are defined, their duration is calculated to identify 
the critical path. 
 
The arrows indicate the sequence of activities. We'll mark the Earliest Start (ES) 
time  to  the  left  of  the  activity,  and  the  Earliest  Finish  (EF)  time  to  the  right
 
 

 
The longest path will be the “critical path”. 
Pert chart 
A PERT chart is a network diagram that allows project managers to create project 
schedules. They’re used in the Program Evaluation Review Technique (PERT) to 
represent  a  project  timeline,  estimate  the  duration  of  tasks,  identify  task 
dependencies and find the critical path of a project. It contains nodes and arrows. 
Nodes represent events or tasks. Arrow represents dependencies between tasks. 
It is a project scheduling and planning tool used to: 
 Represent project activities and their dependencies in a network diagram. 
 Estimate time duration more realistically using three estimates: 
o Optimistic time (O): Minimum possible time. 
o Most likely time (M): Normal/expected time. 
o Pessimistic time (P): Maximum possible time. 
 Expected time for each activity is calculated as: 
TE=(O+4M+P) /6

Step 1: Calculate Expected Time (TE) 
TE=(O+4M+P) /6 
 A: (2 + 4×4 + 6) / 6 = 4 
 B: (3 + 4×5 + 9) / 6 = 5.33 ≈ 5 
 C: (2 + 4×3 + 4) / 6 = 3 
 D: (4 + 4×6 + 10) / 6 = 6.33 ≈ 6 
 E: (3 + 4×4 + 5) / 6 = 4 
 F: (2 + 4×3 + 4) / 6 = 3 
Step 2: Draw Network & Paths

 A → B → D → F 
 A → C → D → F

Step 3: Path Durations 
 Path 1: A (4) + B (5) + D (6) + F (3) = 18 
 Path 2: A (4) + C (3) + D (6) + F (3) = 16

 Critical Path = A → B → D → F 
 Project Expected Duration = 18 days
